name: NPR
text:
Facebook has begun labeling content produced by media outlets it says are under "editorial control" of governments â€” including "Russia Today" and China's "People's Daily."
https://t.co/RZzcyxfUYt

name: NPR
text:
The U.S. is still seeing roughly 20,000 new coronavirus cases a day. 

Hot spots have emerged in California, along with certain counties in every southern state.

"We're very concerned that our public health message isn't resonating," the CDC's head says.
https://t.co/bsWD355Bha

name: NPR
text:
Evangelical Christians traditionally focus on individual sin and salvation. For some, that informs how they confront systemic racism.

"It starts first in your own heart," one pastor says, "then we deal with the racism that exists in the hearts of others." https://t.co/7OjkBaX813

name: NPR
text: Chicago Mayor Lori Lightfoot says police unions are "extraordinarily reluctant to embrace reform" â€” and that addressing police violence "really comes down to change in the culture." https://t.co/ld4ydwLQpy

name: NPR
text:
Some people have mastered sourdough in quarantine. Others took up puzzles or crafts. 
David North built a "Doorway To Imagination" in his backyard. https://t.co/LMnaBBHABn

name: NPR
text: Massive crowds gathered across the nation for some of the biggest protests yet against police brutality, sparked by the May 25th killing of George Floyd by police. https://t.co/hlkEHBghln

name: NPR
text:
George Floyd's family gathered in North Carolina Saturday to honor his life after he was killed by Minneapolis police.
Rev. Dr. Christopher D. Stackhouse said Floyd "sparked the fuse that's going to change this nation," amid protests across the U.S. https://t.co/rhdflAAFvt

name: NPR
text: Tens of thousands of demonstrators protested in Washington, D.C., on Saturday. The protests against racial injustice, sparked by the May 25 police killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis, were the city's biggest yet. https://t.co/5HF9YDuXPx

name: NPR
text:
COVID-19 separated them for 4 weeks â€” the longest they'd ever been apart, aside from his tour in Vietnam. 

April 29: They reunited. From a distance. With masks.

May 8: They had their first kiss. https://t.co/Lxqk8XorRD

name: NPR
text:
"We keep imagining that we can turn police into social workers," author Alex S. Vitale tells @NPRCodeSwitch. 

"But police are violence workers. ... They have the legal capacity to use violence in situations where the average citizen would be arrested." https://t.co/S8Hd6Yiudz

name: NPR
text:
WFSK, a radio station owned by Fisk University, was founded in 1973. 

"The students literally started the station because they wanted to get out the word about prejudice and racist activities in Nashville," says general manager Sharon Kay. https://t.co/YK3KU9eDEp https://t.co/eb5Oxgs6lk

name: NPR
text:
NPR book editor @petramatic shares her book suggestions for summer reading, including:

ðŸ“– "Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes" - Suzanne Collins
ðŸ“– "Get a Life, Chloe Brown" - Talia Hibbert
ðŸ“– "The Giver Quartet" - Lois Lowry
https://t.co/nBhiYMlEZF

name: NPR
text:
"I hope that people ... pay attention to how the characters in this book dream and make jokes and strive even in conditions of great oppression," Megha Majumdar says of "Burning."

"I hope that feels meaningful to anybody picking up the book in the U.S."
https://t.co/fmkD78CT1m

name: NPR
text:
Black America has been hit harder by the coronavirus and job losses. And then there's the other pandemic: systemic racism and discrimination.

Now, black churches â€” born out of resistance â€” are leaders in the response. https://t.co/ujjJ4MpyGv

name: NPR
text: This week, a new prime minister of Kosovo was named â€” something the ousted prime minister Albin Kurti calls a "parliamentary coup d'etat" engineered by political rivals and supported by a U.S. envoy. https://t.co/6t2bblSXym

name: NPR
text:
NEW: Colin Powell, the former secretary of state, says he will vote for Joe Biden â€” and that President Trump's penchant for insulting "anybody who dare[s] to speak against him" has always turned him off.
https://t.co/ro5ifbbJEg

name: NPR
text:
California planned to spend billions this year to prepare communities for future wildfires and climate-driven disasters. But with a $54 billion budget deficit and falling tax revenue, those efforts are now on hold.
 https://t.co/7XqktVp5Yv

name: NPR
text:
The corner of 38th Street and Chicago Avenue in Minneapolis is where George Floyd was killed by police. 

It's where a passerby filmed his killing, posted it online and sparked an uprising.

Now it's where people gather daily to protest, remember and heal.
https://t.co/WOmBVW1HsB

name: NPR
text:
RT @BobbyAllyn: TikTok is now the most downloaded app in the world

Itâ€™s become the go-to place for youth activism around #BLM and #GeorgeFloyd 

But Chinese-owned TikTok has a history of suppression & censorship, and some black creators say thatâ€™s what happening to them

https://t.co/htlnNeplAo

name: NPR
text:
Rev. Najuma Smith-Pollard's son was killed by another man in 2018.

Her advice to those struggling?

"Breathe, pray, meditate â€” breathe. ... And it's ironic that this man died screaming, 'I can't breathe,' and we're back to what we heard Eric Garner say."
https://t.co/3GPPvE72A1

name: NPR
text:
As protests swept the nation, black TikTok creators noticed videos about George Floyd and Black Lives Matter were hard to find. 

The Chinese-owned app â€” which has a history of censorship â€” blamed it on a "technical glitch."

But many remain skeptical.
https://t.co/LLNsmIOtrp

name: NPR
text:
The COVID-19 pandemic has now claimed over 400,000 lives worldwide, according to data collected by Johns Hopkins University. The U.S. â€” at more than 109,000 â€” accounts for more than a quarter of those deaths. 
https://t.co/arWCRPbJjU

name: NPR
text:
Storm surge warnings have been issued for the southeast coast of Louisiana and the Mississippi coast for Sunday due to Tropical Storm Cristobal. 
https://t.co/2mOoK1DZf6
